description: From Middle English atyren, atiren, from Old French atirier (“to equip”), from a- + tire (“rank”), akin to German Zier (“ornament”) and Old Norse tírr (“glory, renown”).

entries.meaning: (clothing) One's dress; what one wears; one's clothes.
examples: He was wearing his formal attire.

entries.meaning: (heraldry) The single horn of a deer or stag.

verbs.description: attire (third-person singular simple present attires, present participle attiring, simple past and past participle attired)

examples: We will attire him in fine clothing so he can make a good impression.
He stood there, attired in his best clothes, waiting for applause.
